monogr.title: The groundworke of conny-catching : the manner of their pedlers-French, and the meanes to vnderstand the same, with the cunning slights of the counterfeit cranke. Therein are handled the practises of the visiter, the fetches of the shifter and rufflar, the deceits of thei doxes ... Done by a justice of peace of great authoritie, who hath had the examining of diuers of them
monogr.author: Harman, Thomas

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: HEere I set before thee (good Reader) the lewd lows • e language of these loytering lusks, and laysie lorrels, wherewith they buy and sell the common people as they passe through the countrey. Which language they tearme Pedlers French, an vnknowne tongue to all but to these bolde beastly bawdy beggers and vaine Vagabonds, beeing halfe mingled with English when it is familiarly talked, and first placing thinges by their proper names, as an Introduction to this peeuish speach.

div.head: The vpright Coffe canteth to the Rogue The vpright man speaketh to the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Vprightman.

p.hi: Bene Lightmans to thy quarromes in what lipkin hast thou liped in this darkemans, whether in a libbeg or in ye strumell.

sp.p: God morrow to thy body, in what house hast thou lyne in all night whether in a bed, or in the strawe.

sp.speaker: Rogue.

p.hi: I couched in a hogshead in a Skipper this darkmans.

sp.p: I laide me downe to sleepe in a barne this night.

sp.speaker: Vprightman.

p.hi: I towre the strummel trine vpon the nabchet and Togman.

sp.p: I see the strawe hang vpon thy cap and coate.

sp.speaker: Rogue.

p.hi: I say by the Salomon I will lage it of with a gage of bene house then cut to my nose watch.

sp.p: I sweare by the masse I will wash it off with a quarte of good drinke then say to me what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Vprightman.

p.hi: Why hast thou any lowre in thy bonge to bouse.

sp.p: Why hast thou any mony in thy purse to drinke.

sp.speaker: Rogue.

p.hi: But a flagge, a win and a make.

sp.p: 〈…〉 half-penny.

sp.speaker: Ʋprightman.

p.hi: Why where is the ken that hath the bene house.

sp.p: Where is the house that hath the good drinke.

sp.speaker: Rogue.

p.hi: A bene morte here by at the signe of the prauncer.

sp.p: A good wife here by at the signe of the horse.

sp.speaker: Ʋprightman.

p.hi: I cutte it is quier house, I bousd a flagge the last darkmans.

sp.p: I say it is a small and naughty drinke, I dranke a groat there last night,

sp.speaker: Rogue.

p.hi: But house there aboord and thou shalt haue benshyp,

sp.p: But drinke there a shilling, and thou shalt haue very good.

p.hi: Tower ye, yonder is the ken, dup the giger and maunde that is beneshyp.

sp.p: See you yonder is the house, opē the dore, & aske for the best.

sp.speaker: Ʋprighman.

p.hi: This is as good as Rome house.

sp.p: This drinke is as good as wine?

p.hi: Now I tower that bene house makes nase nabes.

sp.p: Now I see that good drinke makes a dronken head.

p.hi: Maund of this Morte what bene pecke is in hir ken.

sp.p: Aske of this wife what good meat she hath in hir house.

sp.speaker: Rogue.

p.hi: She hath a Cacling Chete, a gruntinge chete ruffe pecke cassan, and popelars of yarum.

sp.p: She hath a Hen, a Pigge, Baken, Cheese, & Milke porrage

sp.speaker: Ʋprightman.

p.hi: That is beneship to our watche,

sp.p: That is very good for vs.

p.hi: Now we haue well bousd, let vs strike some chete.

sp.p: Now we haue well dronke, let vs steale some thing.

p.hi: Yonder dwelleth aquier cuffen it were beneship to mill him

sp.p: Yonder dwelleth a hoggish and churlish man, it were w • done to robbe him.

sp.speaker: Rogue.

p.hi: Now byng we a wast to the pad the Ruffmans is by.

sp.p: Nay let vs goe hence to the high way the woods is at han •

sp.speaker: Ʋprightman.

p.hi: So may we happen on the harmans, and clye the Iarke, or to the quierken, and skower quier cramprings, and so to tryon the chates.

sp.p: So we may chance to sit in the stocks, or be whipped, or had to prison house, and there be shackled with bolts and fetters, and then to hang on the Gallowes.

sp.speaker: Roge.

p.hi: Gerry gan the Ruffian clye thée.

sp.p: A turd in thy mouth the Diuell take thee.

sp.speaker: Vprightman.

p.hi: What stowe you bene cofe and cut benar whydds & byng we to Rome vyle to nyp a bounge, so shall we haue lower for the bowsing ken, and when we byng back to the deuseuyle, we will fylche some duddes of the Ruffmans or myll the ken for a lage of duddes.

sp.p: What holde your peace good fellowe and speake better wordes, and goe we to London to cut a purse, then we shall haue money for the alehouse, and when wee come backe againe into the countrey, we will steale some lynnen clothes of hedges, or robbe some house for a bucke of clothes.

By this lytle ye may wholy and fully vnderstand their vntoward talke and pelting speech, mingled without measure, and as they haue begun of late to deuise some newe tearmes for certaine things: so will they in time after this, and deuise as euill or worse. This language now being knowne and spred abroad, yet one thing more I will ad vnto, not meaning to English the same, because I learned it of a shameles Doxe, but for the phrase of speech I set it forth onely.

p.hi: There was a Patrico and a nosegent, he tooke his Iockam in his famble and a wapping he went, hee dockt the Dell hee pryg to praunce, he byngd a wast into the darkemans, he fylch the Cofe without any fylch man.
